events.description: Weekly report on US crude oil inventories for the week ending January 30th.
Weekly report on distillate stock levels showing a sharp draw.
A recent period of extreme cold weather that drove heating demand.

facts.fact_text: US heating oil futures steadied around $2.4 per gallon.

evidences.evidence_text: US heating oil futures steadied around $2.4 per gallon

facts.fact_text: US crude inventories fell about 3.46m barrels in the week to January 30th.

evidences.evidence_text: US crude inventories falling about 3.46m barrels in the week to January 30th

facts.fact_text: WTI crude is holding near $64 per barrel.
Distillate stocks posted a sharp draw of roughly 5.55m barrels.

evidences.evidence_text: distillate stocks posted a sharp draw of roughly 5.55m barrels

claims.claim_text: A milder near-term weather outlook curbed expectations for additional heating demand.

evidences.evidence_text: a milder near-term weather outlook curbed expectations for additional heating demand

claims.claim_text: Warmer-than-normal forecasts reduced the market’s ability to extend the late-January rally.

evidences.evidence_text: Warmer-than-normal forecasts through mid-month reduced the market’s ability to extend the late-January rally

claims.claim_text: Crude feedstock dynamics provided support to heating oil prices.

evidences.evidence_text: crude feedstock dynamics provided some support

claims.claim_text: The sharp draw in distillate stocks confirms strong consumption during the recent cold spell.

evidences.evidence_text: confirming strong consumption that already occurred during the recent Arctic cold spell

evidence.evidence_text: a milder near-term weather outlook curbed expectations for additional heating demand
confirming strong consumption that already occurred during the recent Arctic cold spell
crude feedstock dynamics provided some support
